newsitem.title: MACAU: Macau police make arrests linked to crime wave.
newsitem.headline: Macau police make arrests linked to crime wave.

text.p: Police in Macau may have made some progress on Friday in their battle against a crime wave in the Portuguese-run enclave, saying they had arrested a man for arson and another two possibly linked to an execution-style killing.
In a statement, police commander Colonel Fernando Pinto Ribeiro said two illegal immigrants were arrested in the act of burgling the home of the mother of a nurse murdered last month.
Ribeiro said the men were possibly involved in the slaying of the nurse, which police have described as "execution style".

Chinese media in the enclave reported the two immigrants from central China were hired to kill the nurse, who was married to the manager of a company that operates a helicopter shuttle service linking Macau and neighbouring Hong Kong.

Tiny Macau, a territory of 455,000 people perched on China's southern coast, has been hit by a surge in violent crime linked to a turf war over gambling-related businesses between rival mafia-style criminal gangs called "triads".
Fifteen people have been murdered so far this year compared to 21 for the whole of last year, and there have been a series of beatings and arson attacks.
Ribeiro's statement also said police caught a man suspected of being behind a string of arson attacks in the enclave, including the torching of 25 motorcycles outside a police station in February.
The arrest of the 23-year-old man appeared to rule out theories that the motorcycles were set ablaze by triads as a challenge to police authority.
The suspect allegedly committed the arson attacks as a form of "protest" after being sacked from his job at a bank over suspected links to a fraud case, the statement said.
The suspect is now in custody awaiting trial in both the arson and fraud cases.
Police officials from China and Macau agreed on Monday to strengthen cooperation in the fight against cross-border crime.
The enclave shares a 240-metre land border with China and Macau police believe many crimes are committed by mainland Chinese who are able to flee back into China within minutes.
The enclave returns to Chinese rule on December 20, 1999.
The latest surge in crime has even led the United States and Australia to issue warngings to their citizens in Macau.

"U.S. citizens visiting Macau should be aware that the problems have been localised near the casinos during early morning hours and appear to be related to organised crime," the U.S. State Department said in a statement.
